basics.name: Anang Sahroni
basics.label: Geophysicist
basics.summary: PhD student in Paleomagnetism and Geomagnetism with previous experience as computational geophysics

work.name: Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München
work.summary: Studying and conducting research in Paleomagnetism to analyze and characterize the behavior of the Earth's geomagnetic field.

work.name: Geoseismal Research Center
work.summary: Contributed as a developer to various projects, including real-time earthquake monitoring applications, passive seismic data analysis tools, software suites for geomagnetic data analysis, and 3D elastic seismic wave simulation modules. My roles ranged from backend to frontend tasks, utilizing Python and Javascript technologies such as Django, ReactJS, and Electron, and involving tasks like scraping and processing large datasets.

work.name: Indonesia's Ministry of Agrarian Affairs and Spatial Planning/National Land Agency
work.summary: Conducted disaster risk assessments for spatial planning in disaster-prone regions, focusing on creating and integrating hazard maps using GIS to provide essential disaster analysis for disaster risk reduction in spatial planning.

courses: Crustal seismic anisotropy of Sumatra inferred from harmonic decomposition of receiver function.
Determination of the suitable platform and sensor installation procedure on passive seismic acquisition in desert environment using probabilistic power spectral density (PPSD) analysis.

awards.title: Third Winning Team
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'
